Air Situation. 1. The Secretary of State for Air said that a reconnaissance
(Previous of the Heligoland Bight had been carried out in force on the
Reference: previous day, with the object of engaging any enemy warships W.M. (39) 81st which might be sighted. The reconnaissance force had consisted Conclusions, of two formations, each of six Hampden bombers. One of these Minute 1.) formations had attacked two German destroyers. Seven 500-lb.
bombs had been dropped close to one of the destroyers, but no actual hits had been observed. All the aircraft of this formation had returned safely. One aircraft of the other formation had returned to base owing to some defect shortly after taking off, but the other five had failed to return. A German statement had been issued to the effect that a formation of six of our aircraft had attacked their Fleet, but without result; that these aircraft had been subsequently engaged by German fighters, and that five of them had been brought down in the sea. It was to be feared that the German claim to have brought down five of our bombers was probably accurate, but the statement that no damage had been caused to the German ships was not necessarily true.
In discussion, the question was raised whether it would not be more profitable to carry out air attacks on military objectives, such as German troop concentrations. In this connection the Secretary of State for War referred to the information that the Germans were building four pontoon bridges over the Rhine, which would be suitable objectives for air attack.
It was pointed out that the carrying out of attacks on German warships was strictly in accordance with the policy which we had agreed with the French. Nevertheless, it was a matter for consideration whether the continuance of attacks on German warships, close to their bases, constituted the best use of our resources.
The Prime Minister said that the Air Ministry would no doubt take into account the experience gained in bombing attacks already carried out when deciding on future operations.
The War Cabinet took note of the above statement on the Air Situation.

Convoys were sailing according to plan, and certain neutral
ships had taken advantage of the opportunity to join them. If our convoys continued to move in safety, it might be worth inviting neutral shipping to join them, and to insure them against loss on the voyage.
The A quitania had arrived safely from America. She was too fast to move in convoy, and he proposed to enquire of the owners whether the value of her voyages was sufficient to counterbalance the danger of the loss of such a fine ship.
The cruisers which had been searching the South Atlantic, where certain German merchant vessels had been alleged to have a rendezvous, had found nothing and were returning to their stations.
The War Cabinet took note of this statement.

4. The War Cabinet had before them the Weekly Report (No. 4) by the Chiefs of Staff (W.P. (39) 60).
The Minister without Portfolio enquired whether the reference in paragraph 30 to the Divisions " within easy distance of the Belgian and Dutch frontiers" should be understood as the beginnings of a concentration of troops for an attack.
The Chief of the Imperial General Staff said the available information went to show that these Divisions were not those with which we should expect an attack to be carried out. General Gamelin now expected the first attack further south.
Reference was made to telegram No. 132 from Brussels, in which M. Spaak was reported as having said that renewed assurances bad been given by the German authorities to the Dutch and Belgian Military Attache's in Berlin that Germany did not contemplate any attack on the Low Countries.
The War Cabinet took note of the Report by the Chiefs of Staff.

Army in France, which Sir Eric Phipps said that M. Daladier had told him that, at the second meeting of the Supreme War Council, he had pressed that British troops should take their place as early as possible in the Maginot Line and that he still considered this essential to counteract German propaganda.
The Ministers present at the meeting of the Supreme War Council had no recollection of any such request on the part of M. Daladier. The forward movement of the Field Force, which had been discussed, had always been understood to relate to the occupation of its allotted sector, which was not in the Maginot Line.
The Secretary of State for War suggested that there had been a misunderstanding on the part of the British Ambassador. The phrase which had been used by General Gamelin in the discussions which he had attended, had been that the French and British troops should be " side by side," which, in fact, they were in the sector they were occupying. He thought it unlikely that the French Commander-in-Chief would desire the presence of isolated British units in the Maginot Line.
The War Cabinet agreed :
To invite the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs to instruct the British Ambassador in Paris to clear up the misunderstanding which appeared to have occurred.

Efficacy of leaflet campaign.
12. The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs read out a report to the effect that the authorities in Berlin had found that the formation of long queues of persons waiting to buy food provided too free an opportunity for people to exchange ideas. All queues had, therefore, now been prohibited, and people were required to hand their food tickets to the Air Warden of their house by whom the food was purchased.
According to the same report, the leaflet campaign had not as yet proved particularly successful, though it was thought that its effect might be insidious, and prove of greater value later on. Germans picking up leaflets surrendered them to the police, but no doubt in most cases not before they had read them.
The War Cabinet took note of the above statements.

14. The Minister for Co-ordination of Defence said that General Orbay would arrive in London on the 2nd October. The Deputy Chiefs of Staff Committee had prepared an aide-memoire for use by the British Permanent Military Representatives in their discussions with the General, but it was highly desirable that they should be given full instructions before the discussions started. He therefore thought that a Conference of Ministers should be held on Monday morning.
After hearing an account of the position from the Minister for Co-ordination of Defence, the War Cabinet agreed
(i) that a Meeting should be held on Monday, the 2nd October, 1939, at the Central War Room, at 10-45 a.m., to be attended by
The Minister for Co-ordination of Defence, The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, The First Lord of the Admiralty, The Secretary of State for War, The Secretary of State for Air, and The three Chiefs of Staff;
(ii) that this Conference should settle the instructions to be
given to the British Military Representatives as to the line to be taken in their conversations with General Orbay, subject to reference, if need be, to the War Cabinet;
(iii) to take note that, prior to the Meeting referred to in
(i) above, the Minister for Co-ordination of Defence would circulate a Note comparing, under each head, the demands received from the Turkish Government and the extent to which we could meet them;
(iv) that in no circumstances should a situation of real
difficulty be allowed to arise in the conversations with General Orbay until after the Anglo-Turkish Treaty had been actually signed.

In view of the announcement that morning of the German-Soviet Agreement, he (the President of the Board of Trade) had informed the Soviet Trade Commissioner that he must consult his colleagues before he could discuss this suggestion.
The Minister of Supply said that he strongly favoured the conclusion of the first transaction in view of our urgent need for timber. The second transaction presented further difficulties, since a large proportion of the machine tools formerly available had been taken up by the Service Departments. Moreover, it was doubtful whether we were in a position to spare any copper for export.
The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs said that, in reaching a decision, it must be borne in mind that in existing circumstances exports to the U.S.S.R. were probably tantamount to exports to Germany.
The War Cabinet agreed
(a) that the Minister of Supply, in consultation with the
Departments concerned, should be authorised to negotiate as rapidly as possible an agreement with the U.S.S.R. by which the Soviet Union should furnish us with timber in return for rubber and tin (the commodities asked for by the U.S.S.R.), on the understanding that in these negotiations he should secure if possible the insertion of a provision guaranteeing that neither the British vessels now in Archangel and Murmansk nor their crews should be interfered with;
(b) that the President of the Board of Trade should inform the
Soviet Trade Commissioner that, after consultation with his colleagues, he was now in a position to state that he was prepared, in consultation with the Departments concerned, to open negotiations for the purchase of Soviet cereals in exchange for machine tools and copper, in so far as the latter were available for export.

16. The War Cabinet had before them a note on the stage reached in the Sino-Japanese conflict (War Cabinet Paper W.P. (39) 56) prepared by the Chiefs of Staff Committee in amplification of the oral statement made to the War Cabinet by the Chief of the Air Staff at their meeting held on Tuesday, the 26th September, 1939.
In the course of the discussion the following considerations were stressed:
(i) While no one questioned the conclusion reached by the Chiefs of Staff Committee that from the military point of view the prolongation of the Sino-Japanese conflict was to our advantage, it was necessary also to take into consideration the political considerations involved, such as the risk that, if our relations with the Japanese Government further deteriorated, they might stage a series of incidents such as that at Tientsin, to which we should either have to react violently or to be subject
to damaging repercussions, for example, in Siam and in India.

(ii) Doubt was expressed on the question whether, notwith-
standing the last telegram (No. 963 dated the 27th September, 1939), despatched by the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs to His Majesty's Ambassador, Shanghai, Sir Archibald Clark Kerr fully realised that it was not our wish that he should do all in his power to promote a settlement of the Sino-Japanese conflict, but rather that we wished him to sound General Chiang Kai-shek as to his reactions to the suggestion made by the Japanese Government forwarded by Sir Robert Craigie.
Note. In this connection the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs said that Sir Archibald Clark Kerr would not arrive in Chungking until the 7th October, 1939, and that there was therefore plenty of time to send him a further telegram making the position perfectly clear. This would be done.
(iii) The view was expressed that there was no need for a final
decision to be taken at the present time on the question whether the prolongation of the Sino-Japanese conflict was or was not on balance to the interests of this country. If General Chiang Kai-shek was unwilling to enter into discussion with the Japanese Government, no further action on our part would be required. If on the other hand the General favoured such discussions, the matter would in any case need to be further considered by the War Cabinet. The War Cabinet took note of the above discussion.
